text:
Hello all! Is it possible to make a fully interactive notebook running Julia code on a static website with no server code (e,g. buttons, sliders, plots, and manipulating graphics, etc.)? For example, like Pluto.jl notebooks, but exported and embedded on a website while still remaining fully interactive and all computing done on the client-side and not in a server. Or like Makie.jl stuff but all on a website.

I found Genie.jl, Blink.jl, PlotlyJS.jl, but they don't seem to be quite what I'm looking for. I also found some talk on converting Julia to WebAssembly and JavaScript which seems relevant, but that also seemed too low level and I was hoping for something more straightforward. Sorta like how Godot game engine can export to HTML5

text:
Oh! I think I might have found exactly what I was looking for: <https://github.com/SimonDanisch/JSServe.jl>

Though I'm still learning how to use it. If anyone is familiar with it, feel free to chime in

elements.text: Oh! I think I might have found exactly what I was looking for:
Though I'm still learning how to use it. If anyone is familiar with it, feel free to chime in

text: Or maybe not? I'm not sure yet. I'm not sure about the limitations of JSServe and if code can be run or if its just for interactive plots? e.g. some of the examples run on NextJournal which might allow for running code server side

elements.text: Or maybe not? I'm not sure yet. I'm not sure about the limitations of JSServe and if code can be run or if its just for interactive plots? e.g. some of the examples run on NextJournal which might allow for running code server side

text: Maybe ask in <#C017Z6Q3WS3|pluto> because I recall someone having a Pluto notebook as a static page on their website.

elements.text: because I recall someone having a Pluto notebook as a static page on their website.

text: Thank you! I'll ask in the channel. Yeah it'd be great if I could export a Pluto notebook and have users interact with sliders to change plots and simulations on a website

elements.text: Thank you! I'll ask in the channel. Yeah it'd be great if I could export a Pluto notebook and have users interact with sliders to change plots and simulations on a website

text: Though I don’t know about all the compute being on the client side

elements.text: Though I don’t know about all the compute being on the client side

text: Ah I see, no worries. Though I still wonder how they would handle it with server side code running julia though. Not sure how that all fits together. Thank you for the suggestion!
